column1: Parathyroid hyperplasia is the enlargement of all four parathyroid glands.

Parathyroid hyperplasia may occur in people without a family history of the disease, or as part of three inherited syndromes: - Multiple endocrine neoplasia I (MEN I) - MEN IIA - Isolated familial hyperparathyroidism In people with an inherited syndrome, a changed (mutated) gene is passed down through the family.
You only need to get the gene from one parent to develop the condition.
- In MEN I, problems in the parathyroid glands occur, as well as tumors in the pituitary gland and pancreas.
- In MEN IIA, overactivity of the parathyroid glands occurs, along with tumors in the adrenal or thyroid gland.
Bone x-rays and a bone density test (DXA) can help detect fractures, bone loss, and bone softening.
Surgery can sometimes cause hypoparathyroidism, which makes the blood calcium too low.
